construction, measure theory

Construct a Borel subset EEE of the real line R\RR such that for all intervals [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b] we have

0<m(E∩[a,b])<b−a0 < m\p{E \cap \br{a, b}} < b - a0<m(E∩[a,b])<b−a

where mmm denotes Lebesgue measure.
Solution.

Let {rn}n\set{r_n}_n{rn​}n​ be an enumeration of Q\QQ. Define In=(rn−2−n,rn+2−n)I_n = \p{r_n - 2^{-n}, r_n + 2^{-n}}In​=(rn​−2−n,rn​+2−n),

Gn=⋃k≥nIk.G_n = \bigcup_{k \geq n} I_k.Gn​=k≥n⋃​Ik​.

GnG_nGn​ is open since it is a union of open sets. Also GnG_nGn​ contains all but possibly finitely many rational numbers, so it is dense. By construction, Gn+1⊆GnG_{n+1} \subseteq G_nGn+1​⊆Gn​ and

m(Gn)≤∑k=n∞2⋅2−k=4⋅2−n→n→∞0.m\p{G_n} \leq \sum_{k=n}^\infty 2 \cdot 2^{-k} = 4 \cdot 2^{-n} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} 0.m(Gn​)≤k=n∑∞​2⋅2−k=4⋅2−nn→∞​0.

Fix k≥1k \geq 1k≥1. We will construct disjoint sets which remove a small, positive measure portion of IkI_kIk​.

By density of Q\QQ again, for any n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, there exists j≥nj \geq nj≥n such that qj∈Ik  ⟹  Ij∩Ik≠∅q_j \in I_k \implies I_j \cap I_k \neq \emptysetqj​∈Ik​⟹Ij​∩Ik​=∅. Since Ij⊆GnI_j \subseteq G_nIj​⊆Gn​,

m(Ik∩Gn)≥m(Ik∩Ij)>0.m\p{I_k \cap G_n} \geq m\p{I_k \cap I_j} > 0.m(Ik​∩Gn​)≥m(Ik​∩Ij​)>0.

Thus, since m(Gℓ)→0m\p{G_\ell} \to 0m(Gℓ​)→0 as ℓ→∞\ell \to \inftyℓ→∞, there exists ℓ>n\ell > nℓ>n such that

0<m(Gℓ)<m(Ik∩Gn)  ⟹  m(Ik∩Gn∖Gℓ)>0,0 < m\p{G_\ell} < m\p{I_k \cap G_n} \implies m\p{I_k \cap G_n \setminus G_\ell} > 0,0<m(Gℓ​)<m(Ik​∩Gn​)⟹m(Ik​∩Gn​∖Gℓ​)>0,

since Gℓ⊆GnG_\ell \subseteq G_nGℓ​⊆Gn​. Intuitively, any interval IkI_kIk​ will intersect with GnG_nGn​ with positive measure. To get infinitely many of these, we can remove the tail GℓG_\ellGℓ​ of GnG_nGn​ and continue inductively.

Let n1=1n_1 = 1n1​=1, and inductively pick n1<n2<⋯n_1 < n_2 < \cdotsn1​<n2​<⋯ as follows: Given n2k−1n_{2k-1}n2k−1​,

∃n2k>n2k−1 such that m(Ik∩Gn2k−1∖Gn2k)>0, and∃n2k+1>n2k such that m(Ik∩Gn2k∖Gn2k+1)>0.\begin{aligned} \exists &&n_{2k} &> n_{2k-1} &&\text{ such that } m\p{I_k \cap G_{n_{2k-1}} \setminus G_{n_{2k}}} &&> 0, \text{ and} \\ \exists &&n_{2k+1} &> n_{2k} &&\text{ such that } m\p{I_k \cap G_{n_{2k}} \setminus G_{n_{2k+1}}} &&> 0. \end{aligned}∃∃​​n2k​n2k+1​​>n2k−1​>n2k​​​ such that m(Ik​∩Gn2k−1​​∖Gn2k​​) such that m(Ik​∩Gn2k​​∖Gn2k+1​​)​​>0, and>0.​

Moreover, because n⊆m  ⟹  Gm⊆Gnn \subseteq m \implies G_m \subseteq G_nn⊆m⟹Gm​⊆Gn​, it follows that the Gn2k−1∖Gn2kG_{n_{2k-1}} \setminus G_{n_{2k}}Gn2k−1​​∖Gn2k​​ are pairwise disjoint. Set

E=⋃k=1∞Gn2k−1∖Gn2k.E = \bigcup_{k=1}^\infty G_{n_{2k-1}} \setminus G_{n_{2k}}.E=k=1⋃∞​Gn2k−1​​∖Gn2k​​.

Now let I=[a,b]⊆RI = \br{a, b} \subseteq \RI=[a,b]⊆R be such that a<ba < ba<b. If nnn is large enough, then [a+2−n,b−2−n]≠∅\br{a + 2^{-n}, b - 2^{-n}} \neq \emptyset[a+2−n,b−2−n]=∅. Thus, by density, there exists k≥nk \geq nk≥n such that qk∈[a+2−n,b−2−n]q_k \in \br{a + 2^{-n}, b - 2^{-n}}qk​∈[a+2−n,b−2−n], and so

a+2−n≤qk≤b−2−n  ⟹  a≤qk−2−n≤qk+2−n≤b,a + 2^{-n} \leq q_k \leq b - 2^{-n} \implies a \leq q_k - 2^{-n} \leq q_k + 2^{-n} \leq b,a+2−n≤qk​≤b−2−n⟹a≤qk​−2−n≤qk​+2−n≤b,

which means Ik⊆II_k \subseteq IIk​⊆I.

Notice that E∩(Gn2k∖Gn2k+1)=∅E \cap \p{G_{n_{2k}} \setminus G_{n_{2k+1}}} = \emptysetE∩(Gn2k​​∖Gn2k+1​​)=∅ by construction. Indeed, Gn2ℓ−1G_{n_{2\ell-1}}Gn2ℓ−1​​ is always odd, whereas Gn2kG_{n_{2k}}Gn2k​​ is even, and the Gnm∖Gnm+1G_{n_{m}} \setminus G_{n_{m+1}}Gnm​​∖Gnm+1​​ are pairwise disjoint. Consequently, Gn2k∖Gn2k+1⊆EcG_{n_{2k}} \setminus G_{n_{2k+1}} \subseteq E^\compGn2k​​∖Gn2k+1​​⊆Ec, which means

m(I∖E)≥m(Ik∖E)≥m(Ik∩Gn2k∖Gn2k+1)>0.\begin{aligned} m\p{I \setminus E} \geq m\p{I_k \setminus E} \geq m\p{I_k \cap G_{n_{2k}} \setminus G_{n_{2k+1}}} > 0. \end{aligned}m(I∖E)≥m(Ik​∖E)≥m(Ik​∩Gn2k​​∖Gn2k+1​​)>0.​

On the other hand,

m(E∩I)≥m(E∩Ik)≥m(Ik∩Gn2k−1∖Gn2k)>0.m\p{E \cap I} \geq m\p{E \cap I_k} \geq m\p{I_k \cap G_{n_{2k-1}} \setminus G_{n_{2k}}} > 0.m(E∩I)≥m(E∩Ik​)≥m(Ik​∩Gn2k−1​​∖Gn2k​​)>0.

Hence, 0<m(E∩I)<m(I)0 < m\p{E \cap I} < m\p{I}0<m(E∩I)<m(I), which was what we wanted.
